text:
Diffractor (WIP - still some known performance bugs):
```julia> @time @eval sin'''(1.0)
  2.097331 seconds (2.49 M allocations: 149.539 MiB, 5.42% gc time, 16.26% compilation time)
-0.5403023058681398

julia> @time @eval sin'''(1.0)
  0.004400 seconds (2.94 k allocations: 172.250 KiB)
-0.5403023058681398

julia> @time @eval cos'''(1.0)
  0.694849 seconds (673.50 k allocations: 39.477 MiB, 2.19% gc time, 1.85% compilation time)
0.8414709848078965

julia> @time @eval cos'''(1.0)
  0.003586 seconds (3.05 k allocations: 178.844 KiB)
0.8414709848078965```
Zygote:
```julia> @time @eval sin'''(1.0)
102.234250 seconds (118.05 M allocations: 6.487 GiB, 3.14% gc time, 99.91% compilation time)
-0.5403023058681398

julia> @time @eval sin'''(1.0)
  0.009297 seconds (4.33 k allocations: 1.535 MiB)
-0.5403023058681398

julia> @time @eval cos'''(1.0)
 66.910576 seconds (39.20 M allocations: 2.066 GiB, 1.48% gc time, 99.80% compilation time)
0.8414709848078965

julia> @time @eval cos'''(1.0)
  0.009765 seconds (4.34 k allocations: 1.517 MiB)
0.8414709848078965```

text: What I'd be pretty curious to see would be some benchmarks involving broadcasting and perhaps even just something like differentiating `x -> x.m` while only defining a rule for `getfield`. Just because Zygote is pretty bad at those. Extra points for inferrable higher order derivatives of course.
